_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



Regulated Substance and Stationary Source



The Southeastern Mills, Inc. facility in Rome, GA now has sister company Milner Milling Company performing milling onsite. The facility is in the business of milling wheat into various flours to be used in baking food products.  Wheat, by its nature, can carry a variety of bacteria and spores on its surface.  This flora can produce undesirable or harmful qualities in finished products.  Controlled introduction of chlorine gas into the flour during milling reduces the flora to acceptable levels.  Further, chlorine produces reactions in the raw flour which can be advantageous in the baking process.



Pressurized chlorine is stored as liquid in one ton cylinders at the mill. Chlorine is introduced into the milling system via multiple tank connections to a common manifold d to the demand rate required by the mill.  Chlorine is drawn through a Gas Pressure Reducing Valve and a Vacuum Regulator and Pressure Check unit, and enters the chlorinators under vacuum rather than under pressure.  This greatly reduces the probability of a leak of chlorine from the chlorine delivery piping.  



The maximum intended inventory of chlorine at this site is 16,000 pounds, which exceeds the EPA's threshold quantity of 2,500 pounds.  Milner Milling is therefore subject to RMP requirements under CAA 112 (r).





Prevention of Chlorine Release



The process is designed and maintained in compliance with recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices as shown in the Process Safety information that is incorporated within the Process Safety Management (PSM) document on file at the facility.  It is Milner Milling's policy to adhere to all applicable Federal and State rules and regulations.  Safety depends on the manner in which we operate and maintain the chlorine storage and dispensing system.  We have retained Corbion Caravan, a nationally recognized expert firm, to perform all periodic and preventive maintenanc

e, and to provide frequent and thorough training to our personnel.  Safety and maintenance procedures outlined in the PSM are followed, and will minimize the potential of a release of chlorine to the environment.



Five Year Accident History



No accidental releases have occurred in the past five years.



Emergency Response Program



Despite the Prevention Program noted above, incidents may still occur.  Milner Milling works with emergency responders of the Rome-Floyd Emergency Management Agency, who are trained and equipped to respond to a release.  Their phone number is (706) 236-4543.  Further, appropriate Milner Milling personnel are trained and informed to contact the National Response Center at (800) 424-8802.
